greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of distinct integers encountered on possible paths from n to 1 when iterating the nondeterministic map k -> k - k/p, where p is any of the prime factors of k.
comment: The count includes also n itself, and the final 1 when it is distinct from n.
a(n) >= A000005(n) because all divisors of n can be found in the union of those paths. - _Antti Karttunen_, Apr 19 2020
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..20000
formula: a(p) = 1 + a(p-1) for all primes p.
example: a(6): we have two alternative paths: {6, 4, 2, 1} or {6, 3, 2, 1}, with numbers [1, 2, 3, 4, 6] present, therefore a(6) = 5;
a(12): we have three alternative paths: {12, 8, 4, 2, 1}, {12, 6, 4, 2, 1} or {12, 6, 3, 2, 1}, with numbers [1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12] present, therefore a(12) = 7;

a(14): we have five alternative paths: {14, 12, 8, 4, 2, 1}, {14, 12, 6, 4, 2, 1}, {14, 12, 6, 3, 2, 1}, {14, 7, 6, 4, 2, 1} or {14, 7, 6, 3, 2, 1}, with numbers [1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 8, 12, 14] present in at least one of the paths, therefore a(14) = 9.
mathematica: a[n_] := Block[{lst = {{n}}}, While[lst[[-1]] != {1}, lst = Join[ lst, {Union[ Flatten[# - #/(First@# & /@ FactorInteger@#) & /@ lst[[-1]]]]}]]; Length@ Union@ Flatten@ lst]; Array[a, 75] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Apr 06 2020 *)
program: A332809list(up_to) = { my(v=vector(up_to)); v[1] = Set([1]); for(n=2,up_to, my(f=factor(n)[, 1]~, s=Set([n])); for(i=1,#f,s = setunion(s,v[n-(n/f[i])])); v[n] = s); apply(length,v); }
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Apr 04 2020
